contentrichtext.text: Sir '''Walter Parratt''' [[Knight Commander of the Royal Victorian Order|KCVO]] (10 February 1841{{spaced ndash}}27 March 1924) was an [[England|English]] [[organist]] and [[composer]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Obituary: WALTER PARRATT|journal=Musical Times|year=1924|month=May 1,|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/913981}}</ref> ==Biography== Born in [[Huddersfield]], son of a parish organist, Parratt began to play the [[pipe organ]] from an early age, and held posts as an organist while still a child. He was child prodigy: on one occasion he played [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]]'s complete ''[[The Well-Tempered Clavier]]'' by heart, without notice, at the age of only ten.<ref>Grove's Dictionary, 5th edition, 1954, Vol. 6, p. 559</ref> From 1854 to 1861 he was an organist at St Paul's Church in his native town and, as successor to [[John Stainer]], in 1872 at [[Magdalen College, Oxford]], where he remained for ten years. From 1882 he held the post of organist of [St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle]. He became [[Heather Professor of Music]] at [[Oxford University]] in 1908, taking over from [[Hubert Parry]]. He had previously been Organist and Fellow of Magdalen College, Oxford. He became one of the foremost organ teachers of his day, with many important posts in Britain being filled by his students. He was president of the [[Royal College of Organists]]. Parratt was also a distinguished chess player, and was able to simultaneously play chess and a complex organ piece--at first sight.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Pearson | first = Arthur | title = Famous Yorkshire Musicians | journal = The Non-Conformist Musical Journal | volume = 186 | issue = | pages = 73, 88–90 | date = June 1903 | url = http://books.google.com/books?id=RecqAAAAYAAJ&dq=Walter%20Parratt&pg=RA3-PA89#v=onepage&q=Walter%20Parratt&f=false | accessdate = 2010-03-24}}</ref> He served for a few months as president of the [[Oxford University Chess Club]] and for two years was captain of the eight chosen to play against Cambridge.<ref>{{cite journal|title='''PARRATT, Sir Walter'''|journal=Who's Who,|year=1907|volume= 59|pages=p. 1359|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=yEcuAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1359}}</ref> ==Honours== He was [[knight]]ed in 1892. In 1893 he was appointed [[Master of the Queen's Music|Master of the Queen's Musick]] to [[Queen Victoria]], and afterward held the same office under Kings [[Edward VII of the United Kingdom|Edward VII]]<ref>{{LondonGazette |issue=27363 |date=8 October 1901 |startpage=6569}}</ref> and [[George V of the United Kingdom|George V]]. Later honours included: Member (MVO, 1901), Commander (CVO, 1917), and Knight Commander (KCVO, 1921) of the [[Royal Victorian Order]]. After Parratt's death in 1924 a monument to him was erected in the grounds of Huddersfield Parish Church. There is also a monument to him in St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle, next to the entrance to King George VI Memorial Chapel where King George VI and the Queen mother are buried. ==Appointments== *Armitage Bridge Church, 1852-1854 *St. Paul's Church, Huddersfield, 1854-1861 *private organist to the Earl of Dudley, [[Witley Court]], 1861-1868 *organist of [[Wigan Parish Church]], 1868-1872 *[[Magdalen College, Oxford]], 1872-1882 *[[St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle]] 1882-1924 {{start box}} {{s-court}} {{succession box|title=[[Master of the Queen's Music|Master of the Queen's (later King's) Musick]]|before=Sir [[William Cusins]]|after=Sir [[Edward Elgar]]|years=1893–1924}} {{end box}} ==See also== * [[Malcolm Boyle]] ==References== {{reflist}} *Rosemary Firman, ‘Parratt, Sir Walter (1841–1924)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/35392, accessed 25 March 2008] *[[Donald Tovey]] & Geoffrey Parratt, ''Walter Parratt: Master Of The Music'' (Oxford University Press, 1941). *[http://www.thamesweb.co.uk/windsor/castle/stgeorge_organ.html Organ Recitals at St George's Chapel] {{Authority control|VIAF=32190353}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Parratt, Walter | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 10 February 1841 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 27 March 1924 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Parratt, Walter}} [[Category:1841 births]] [[Category:1924 deaths]] [[Category:English composers]] [[Category:English classical organists]] [[Category:Masters of the Queen's Music]] [[Category:People from Huddersfield]] [[Category:Knights Bachelor]] [[Category:Composers awarded knighthoods]] [[Category:Musicians awarded knighthoods]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Royal Victorian Order]] [[Category:Fellows of Magdalen College, Oxford]]
